central_thesis: The Scroll of Set functions as an internal communiqué for the Temple of Set, detailing personal experiences with Setian philosophy and practical magic, community updates, and explorations into esoteric concepts like telepathy and ritual design, all aimed at the advancement and self-deification of its members within the Setian tradition.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] "Start at the Beginning; It's no Shame." Biography: Robertt W. Neilly III°
structure_content.summary: This section introduces Robertt W. Neilly, a newly recognized Priest in the Temple of Set. It details his journey into Setianism (from Church of Satan Iº to Setian Iº and Adept IIº), his magical name 'Delphic,' and his personal aspirations within the Temple, emphasizing understanding, empathy with the Elect, and attaining 'natural power of magic.' He is also noted as a co-founder of the C.A.T.E. (Combined Astral Telepathic Experiments) and contributor to a related article.

Ricco Zappitelli, a Priest and 'other resident' of XemSet, provides an update on XemSet activities. He describes an upcoming Autumnal Equinox celebration focused on reaffirming past efforts and creating a 'bubble of protection' around XemSet against external interference, particularly efforts to make owner-built homes illegal. This follows previous Spring Equinox and Summer Solstice workings aimed at growth and strengthening community links. A Hallows Eve ritual is also teased.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Straight for the Heart - A Movie Review: Dracula
structure_content.summary: Linda Thomas offers an esoteric interpretation of the movie 'Dracula,' viewing it as a tragedy about the 'murder of the heart' and the societal suppression of inner darkness. Drawing parallels with Nietzsche and the 'Book of Coming Forth by Night,' she argues that society externalizes fear by creating 'demons,' whereas Setian philosophy encourages befriending this inner darkness ('Maat the heart') to discover Set and oneself in opposition, challenging 'natural law.'

This section presents two aphorisms: one by Jack Smith defining education as moving from 'cocksure ignorance to thoughtful uncertainty,' and another by 'Knight's Law' stating 'Life is what happens to you while you are making other plans.' These serve as philosophical interjections.

A poem by Susan Wylie describes a transcendent journey into an 'other sphere,' a place of wonder and strange beauty, where familiar concepts are re-experienced with awe and disbelief. It suggests a profound, unearthly experience that leaves a lasting impression upon returning to ordinary life.

Lynn Norton explains her methods for receiving new Tarot card designs for the Temple of Set. She describes two approaches: receiving strong mental pictures that must be committed to paper, and ritually producing designs (e.g., the 'Golden Section') in her chamber. An artist translates these into paintings, aiming for 'incredible power and beauty' that illustrate philosophical or physical realities.

structure_content.chapter_title: [7] Transition in Toronto: Ordination of Robertt Neilly, 8/18/XIV
structure_content.summary: This section offers a poetic account of Robertt Neilly's ordination as a Priest of Set. It describes the ritual's atmosphere (darkness, soft music), key phrases ('You have Come into Being,' 'I hereby ordain you as a Priest of Set'), symbolic elements (Nekhbet's feathers, an amulet), and the spiritual transference of 'Essence' from a 'Brother of Darkness.' The experience is portrayed as a 'finding after seeking' and a moment of powerful, real yet unreal magic.

Corey Cole recounts early failures in practical magic, particularly a 'destruction ritual' for a cold, attributing it to incorrect 'imagery and symbolism' and a misunderstanding of Set's nature. He later succeeded by invoking Set as a witness to strengthen his will and Dioncecht (Celtic physician god) as a principle of healing, emphasizing that success requires 'expecting success,' correct imagery, and directing one's Will. The Temple, he notes, helped strengthen his Will through communication with Set and 'sharing of essence.'

Robertt Neilly analyzes the results of the C.A.T.E.-II (Combined Astral Telepathic Experiments), acknowledging high scores among participants like Constance Moffatt II°. He discusses the nuances of scoring 'hits' versus 'misses' and the differing significance of a 'pentagram' hit versus an 'irregular rock' due to popularity. He concludes that the experiments lay groundwork for smaller, more controlled studies to improve Setian telepathic abilities, potentially leading to a symbolic communication system.

This section announces the resignations of Colleen Huddleston and Marie Kelly, accepted by Magus Ronald Barrett. It also notes the appointment of Magistra Lilith Sinclair as Executive Director, pending Council approval.

Steve Bushey provides etymological and historical details about October, including its Latin origin, Slavic and Anglo-Saxon names, associated magical stones (beryl, tourmaline, opal), and the corresponding Egyptian deity (Het-Heru/Hathor).

key_concepts.definition: A philosophy and magical practice within the Temple of Set, centered around the Egyptian god Set. It emphasizes self-deification, individual Will, the exploration of inner darkness, and operating in opposition to conventional norms. Set is perceived as a being of power and will, not healing or compassion.

The core operative faculty of the individual Setian, considered central to effective magic. It is strengthened through philosophical alignment, personal experience, and communication with Set, often involving a 'sharing of essence.' Directing Will towards desired outcomes is paramount.

A vital spiritual or energetic component that can be shared or transferred, particularly during initiations (e.g., ordination) or through direct communication with Set. This transfer contributes to the strengthening of an individual's Will and magical capability.

An esoteric concept within Setian philosophy, referring to the 'innermost Darkness of our hearts.' It is presented as a place where one confronts and befriends what others might term 'Demons,' ultimately leading to the discovery of Set and the self in opposition.

A structured series of experimental workings within the Temple of Set designed to study and develop telepathic communication among members. It involves sending and receiving images or concepts, with analysis of results aimed at creating reliable symbolic communication systems.

Critical elements in Setian ritualistic workings. The correctness and intentionality of imagery and symbolism are vital for aligning one's Will with the desired outcome and achieving successful magical results. Misaligned imagery can lead to failure.

A specific location or community within the Temple of Set, actively engaged in ritual work for communal growth, strengthening bonds, and generating protective magical fields. It is a site where Setian philosophy is applied in a practical, community-focused manner.

Invoked not as an anthropomorphic being, but as a 'principle of healing' within a practical magical context. It is used in conjunction with strengthened Will and Set as a witness to achieve specific healing outcomes.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in The Scroll of Set is centered on cultivating individual Will and self-awareness through an active engagement with Setian philosophy. It involves the application of specific ritual mechanics, emphasizing correct imagery, symbolism, and a strong 'expectation of success.' Magic is understood as the direction of one's internal Will, rather than reliance on external forces, with the Temple providing a framework for members to strengthen their Will through communication with Set and 'sharing of essence.'
tools: Individual Will: The central operative tool, requiring strengthening and precise direction.
Imagery & Symbolism: Crucial for constructing effective rituals, aligning magical intent, and achieving desired results.
Communication with Set: A method for strengthening individual Will and receiving 'sharing of essence.'
Dioncecht: Invoked as a 'principle of healing' for specific applications, rather than as an anthropomorphic deity.
Pen and Paper: Used in Tarot design rituals to record initial visions and generated images.
Key Symbols (for C.A.T.E.): Proposed to be developed for reliable and repeatable telepathic communication.
rituals: Autumnal Equinox Celebration: A communal working at XemSet for reaffirming past efforts, reinforcing community, and creating a 'bubble of protection' against external interference.
Spring Equinox & Summer Solstice Workings: Communal rituals at XemSet aimed at fostering growth, closeness, and awareness within the Temple, and solidifying community links.
Ordination Ritual: An initiatory rite for Priesthood, involving specific phrases, symbolic elements, and a transfer of 'Essence' from an officiating Priest.

Destruction Rituals: Designed to eliminate unwanted influences (e.g., illness). Effectiveness relies on correct imagery, understanding the nature of invoked forces (Set as power/will), and directing one's Will.
Tarot Design Rituals: Methods for receiving and actualizing new Tarot card designs, either through strong mental visions or ritually induced generation.

relevant_quotes.text: "Be objective. Detach yourself. Look on all sides and past the blinders we are used to."

"To me the Temple means an association with intelligent individuals in the truest sense, persons with whom I am able to communicate. It represents the highest possible order of learning, and so far the closest I have been to the Prince of Darkness."
"Start at the beginning ... It's no shame,"
"You have Come into Being, and I have cone to open the Door."
"I hereby ordain you as a Priest of Set."
"As it is visualized, so it is done."
"Education is the process of moving from cocksure ignorance to thoughtful uncertainty."
"Life is what happens to you while you are making other plans."
"But speak to me at night, for the sky then becomes an entrance and not a barrier."

"How did I endure it? How did I recover from such wounds, how did I overcome them? How did my soul arise again from those graves? Yes, something invulnerable, unburiable is within me, something that rends rocks: it is called my Will."

critical_analysis.relevance: The Scroll of Set provides a highly relevant and unique snapshot into the internal workings, philosophical interpretations, and practical magical pursuits of the Temple of Set during September 1979. It demonstrates how Setian philosophy is applied to individual self-development, community cohesion, and the operational aspects of magic, including experimental telepathy and ritual construction. The document highlights the emphasis on intellect, individual will, and a distinct approach to esoteric concepts.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the existing members of the Temple of Set, particularly those actively involved in its philosophical and practical work, serving as an internal journal for updates, discourse, and shared experiences. Secondary audiences include external researchers, academics, or practitioners interested in modern esoteric currents, specifically the unique expression of Setianism, its blend of self-empowerment, intellectual rigor, and practical magic, and its historical development.
